segments.text: I'm very happy to meet you by the way.
It was very nice to talk to you.
I'm used to talk to people.
You are my first.
And also, you know, you are a scholar first.
And very often, if you meet journalists, they are not so scholars.
Well, they don't read the books first.
No, that's one thing.
And the other thing is also that you are a bibliomania.
I specialize in books.
All I write about is books and authors.
And it's always a question, bibliomania.
What is the word?
I even traced the history of the Lord.
I traced it to his first years.
And I even wrote Bernard Knox.

You're completely right.

Why don't you tell, what is your theory, what is your theory, you know?

you can manage to write again, because, you know, of course, everything.

to write a little book, philosophical book, a book for wondering for young children, six years old.

and to read, you know, like that.

You know, one thing I really should say is that, you know, in Norway and baby here, something has been very common lately, recently, and that is the so-called baby swimming lessons, you know?
We've had them here, right?
Yeah.
What it is about is that you run into a hospital, take this midwife away, and take the kid, run to a swimming pool, throw the kid in the swimming pool, and the kid is not drowning.
Because it's an inborn ability, you know, to manage the water.
I think in the same way, to wonder about life is an inborn ability.
But it has to be pendant.
In a way, to wonder about life is nothing we learn.
It's something we forget.
We don't learn to wonder about life.
We forget to wonder about life.
So, then I think that to wonder about life must depend the truth.
It looks like if we don't learn to swim as babies, we have to go to swimming school.

If you don't start philosophy as young and keep it standard, then we have to go to philosophy school as adults.

However, we do have an institution in Norway called Examen Philosophikum.
which all students must pass before they go on studying biology, language, history, anything.
So that means that we have really a great philosophical milieu, you know.
So in Oslo there lives 600,000 people, you know, but there are 60 philosophy teachers, you know, 60 philosophy teachers.
Six, is that a lot?
Sixty.
Sixty, that is a lot.
It's in a town with 600,000 people, and there are 60 philosophy teachers, because it's a student town, and all students have to reflect it.
Maybe.
So my book is, in a way, a reflex of this huge philosophical milieu, in a way.
Okay.
